data.title: Jane Street scandal exposed
data.description:
This powerful trading firm, which you may have never heard of, has been caught red-handed. And twice, on two different continents. This is precisely why Bitcoin has finally gained its freedom. Let me explain: Jane Street Group is a New York-based quantitative trading firm. They don't have a CEO. According to their own description, they operate like an "anarchist commune." In the first nine months of 2025 alone, their net trading revenue reached $24 billion, surpassing their total revenue of $20.5 billion for the entire year of 2024. In the second quarter of 2025 alone, their revenue reached $10.1 billion, the highest quarterly trading revenue ever recorded by any Wall Street firm. From any perspective, they are the most profitable trading firm in the world. This week, the bankruptcy administrator of Terraform Labs filed a lawsuit in Manhattan federal court, accusing Jane Street of using insider information to manipulate the Terra Luna crash in May 2022. This crash wiped out $40 billion in market capitalization and triggered a chain reaction, ultimately leading to the collapse of companies such as Celsius, Three Arrows Capital, and FTX. The accusation is shockingly simple. On May 7, 2022, Terraform Labs quietly withdrew $150 million worth of UST from Curve3pool, a large decentralized liquidity pool. There was no public announcement; the liquidity was withdrawn silently. Ten minutes later, a wallet associated with Jane Street withdrew $85 million from the same liquidity pool. Just ten minutes later. The lawsuit alleges that former Terraform intern Bryce Pratt (who joined Jane Street as a full-time employee in September 2021) established secret contacts with his former colleagues at Terraform. He allegedly passed significant, non-public information regarding changes in Terraform liquidity directly to Jane Street's trading department. The lawsuit names four defendants: Jane Street Group LLC, co-founder Robert Granieri, and employees Bryce Pratt and Michael Huang. The administrator's statement hits the nail on the head: Jane Street conducted "trades that would have been impossible without its unique insider information." Worse still, the lawsuit claims Jane Street's withdrawal triggered the decoupling from UST, causing the entire Terraform ecosystem to collapse. LUNA's price plummeted from over $80 to near zero, wiping out $40 billion. Ordinary people suffered devastating losses; retirement savings, children's education funds, and life's work vanished in just a few days. What was Jane Street's response? They called it "desperate" and "baseless." But the problem is: this wasn't the first time they'd done something like this. In July 2025, the Securities and Exchange Commission of India (SEBI) filed one of the most serious market manipulation charges against Jane Street in the country's history. The SEBI investigation found that Jane Street had engaged in textbook pump-and-dump operations on the Bank Nifty index across 18 derivative maturities between January 2023 and March 2025.

Their methods were highly mechanical:

In the morning: Jane Street's algorithm heavily bought the constituent stocks of the bank stock index and their futures, pushing the index up by 1% to 1.3%. SEBI found that on some trading days, Jane Street alone had the entire impact on the index's rise.

At the same time, they bought a large number of short options, mainly selling call options and buying put options, in a ratio severely imbalanced with their stock holdings. SEBI found that, calculated by delta, option holdings were 7.3 times that of stock and futures holdings. This is not hedging or arbitrage, but rather directional manipulation with additional steps.

Afternoon: They reversed their actions, selling all the stocks they had bought in the morning. The index fell, and the short options profited. This operation was repeated every expiry date. The Securities and Exchange Commission of India (SEBI) assessed that the illegal profits amounted to 48.43 billion rupees, approximately $580 million. The SEBI called Jane Street's actions "a means of deliberately manipulating settlement prices." They noted that Jane Street continued this strategy even after the National Stock Exchange of India (NSE) issued a clear warning in February 2025. The SEBI's wording was unusually harsh for the regulator: "The integrity of the market, and the trust of millions of small investors and traders, can no longer be held hostage by such untrustworthy manipulators." Jane Street was subsequently banned from the Indian securities market. They deposited over $560 million into a third-party escrow account and immediately filed an appeal. As of now, the case is still being heard in the Indian Securities Appeals Court. Now let's talk about Bitcoin. Since November 2025, Bitcoin traders have noticed some strange phenomena. Every morning around 10 AM (Eastern Time), when the US stock market opens, the selling volume of Bitcoin and its related ETFs increases significantly. This pattern is unusually stable. Bitcoin surges overnight during Asian and European trading sessions, then immediately plummets after the New York Stock Exchange opens. (For details, please refer to Trading View's analysis and statistics)

These numbers are significant. The chart from December 2025 shows that on some days, the price of Bitcoin plummeted from $89,700 to $87,700 within minutes, resulting in losses of up to $171 million for leveraged long positions before recovering. This occurred repeatedly on December 1st, 5th, 8th, 10th, 12th, 15th, and in January and February 2026.

... The crypto Twitter community calls this the "10am crash." The blame is being placed on Jane Street, and for good reason. Jane Street is one of only four authorized participants in BlackRock's IBIT (the world's largest spot Bitcoin ETF). The other three are Virtu Americas, JPMorgan Securities, and Marex. As an authorized participant, Jane Street has unique authority to create and redeem ETF shares, meaning they are directly involved in the flow of Bitcoin among institutional investors. Their 13F filings confirm their large holdings. As of the third quarter of 2025, Jane Street held $5.7 billion worth of IBIT stock. They added another $276 million in the fourth quarter of 2025, bringing their total holdings to over 20 million shares, worth approximately $790 million at year-end prices. At its peak, their IBIT stock holdings were worth close to $2.5 billion. However, what is suspicious is that Jane Street allegedly sold off spot Bitcoin every morning, while simultaneously increasing their holdings of MSTR (Strategy, formerly MicroStrategy) stock by 473% in the fourth quarter of 2025, accumulating 951,187 shares, worth approximately $121 million. Meanwhile, other large funds, such as BlackRock and Vanguard, were selling billions of dollars worth of MSTR stock. Think about it: sell Bitcoin at the open, causing a price crash, liquidating leveraged long positions, and then buying it back at an even lower price. Simultaneously, buy large amounts of the most leveraged Bitcoin alternatives on the market, then wait for the inevitable rebound. Glassnode co-founders Jan Happel and Yann Allemann reignited this theory through their Negentropic account, linking algorithmic trading to the Terraform lawsuit. The Milk Road account further reinforced the theory, describing "persistent rumors" about institutional trading departments operating "very specific/questionable operating manuals." Then the lawsuit was filed. Then something extraordinary happened. The expected 10am crash after Terraform filed its lawsuit against Jane Street…didn't happen. For the first time in months, Bitcoin didn't crash at the US open. Instead, it rose. On February 25, 2026, Bitcoin surged over 3%, breaking through multiple resistance levels and trading above $68,000, whereas just days earlier it might have even fallen below $60,000. Over $323 million in short positions were liquidated. The Stochastic Relative Strength Index (Stochastic RSI) reached 100. ETFs saw a record $257.7 million in inflow in a single day, the highest since early February. This pattern has been broken. Now, I want to be cautious. Correlation does not equal causation. Multiple factors are at play: Trump's State of the Union address, oversold technical conditions, and short covering. The Fear & Greed Index reached 11, indicating extreme panic, which typically signals a turning point for contrarian trading. The RSI fell to 15.80, a level not seen since the 2020 COVID-19 crash, which was followed by a 1400% rebound. But timing is not to be ignored. Rumors are circulating on X that Jane Street was "forced to shut down their trading algorithm" after the lawsuit. Jane Street told Cointelegraph that these claims are "baseless and opportunistic accusations." Whether they were forced to stop or chose to suspend operations out of legal caution, the result was the same: the selling pressure disappeared. What does this really mean for Bitcoin? Spot Bitcoin ETFs were initially expected to act as market equalizers. They had institutional access, were regulated products, and were endorsed by BlackRock. And they did achieve tremendous success, with IBIT alone raising over $20 billion since its launch. However, the structure of ETFs introduced something Bitcoin originally intended to circumvent: privileged, trusted intermediaries with access to the core trading system. When the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) approved spot Bitcoin ETFs in January 2024, it stipulated that subscriptions and redemptions could only be made in cash. Each time subscriptions or redemptions were needed, someone had to buy and sell actual Bitcoin. The institutions participating in this process, i.e., authorized participants, possess a structural advantage over all other participants in the market. In September 2025, the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) approved the physical creation and redemption of IBIT, meaning authorized participants can now directly exchange Bitcoin for ETF units without going through fiat currency. This gives institutions like Jane Street, Virtu, JPMorgan Chase, and Marex greater direct control over Bitcoin inflows and outflows in this largest institutional-grade ETF. The 10am plunge is essentially a symptom of the same intractable problem that has plagued the gold market for decades. As I explained in my article "The Beginning of the Gold Endgame": the competition between simulated trading platforms allows institutions with the most privileges to manipulate prices before other market participants can react. JPMorgan Chase traders Greg Smith and Michael Novak were convicted of fraud in the precious metals futures market, a scheme that lasted eight years and involved thousands of illegal transactions. JPMorgan Chase paid a $920 million settlement. Deutsche Bank also paid $30 million for the same offense. UBS, HSBC, and six individual traders faced charges from the Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) for violating anti-fraud measures. Same tactics, different assets. Each time, these companies called it "market making," "arbitrage," or "hedging"—the euphemisms are numerous. The result is always the same: ordinary people get ripped off, while insiders profit. So, what do we do next? The broader structural problems haven't changed. The $4.5 billion outflow from ETFs in the first eight weeks of 2026 is worrying, but Strategy (Saylor's company) just bought $39 million worth of Bitcoin, accounting for 99% of all publicly traded companies' Bitcoin purchases during that period. Large institutions aren't selling off; they're waiting for the algorithm to finish its work. Perhaps, the algorithm really has. If Jane Street is forced to halt its so-called daily sell-off program (whether due to legal risks, multi-continental regulatory scrutiny, or simply self-preservation), the structural resistance that has plagued Bitcoin for four months will be eliminated. Bitcoin was born for this moment. It is a monetary system that does not rely on trusted intermediaries, requires no authorized participants, and cannot be preemptively traded by former interns through private channels. But let's not forget what brought us to this point. Companies that were supposed to be "market makers" and "liquidity providers" have been accused of front-trading, manipulating national stock indices, and running daily algorithmic sell-off programs to trade assets tracked by their ETFs. And this is precisely the system that Bitcoin aims to replace.

data.title: Deciphering EF's Latest Protocol Roadmap: Is It Officially Entering the Era of Engineering Upgrades?
data.description:
Written by:imToken

On February 18th, the Ethereum Foundation (EF) released the "Protocol Priorities Update for 2026." Compared to previous fragmented updates centered around EIPs, this roadmap is more like a strategic schedule, clearly defining the upgrade pace, priority allocation, and the three main themes that the protocol layer will revolve around in the coming year: Scale, Improve UX, and Harden the L1.

Behind this, from the successful delivery of the two hard forks (Pectra/Fusaka) in 2025 to the early planning of the dual main themes of Glamsterdam and Hegotá in 2026, we have also seen a profound shift in Ethereum development towards "predictable engineering delivery," which may be the most important protocol layer signal in recent years.

I. Ethereum in 2025: Turmoil and Institutionalization

If you've been following Ethereum, you'll know that 2025 was a year of intertwined contradictions for the protocol. While the price of ETH may have hovered at a low level, the protocol layer underwent unprecedented and intensive changes.

Especially in early 2025, Ethereum experienced a rather awkward period. At that time, EF was at the center of a media storm—community criticism was rampant, and some even called for the introduction of a so-called "wartime CEO" to drive change. Ultimately, a series of internal power struggles became public, forcing the highest-level power reorganization in EF's history: In February, Executive Director Aya Miyaguchi was promoted to President, and Vitalik Buterin promised to restructure the leadership; Subsequently, Hsiao-Wei Wang and Tomasz K. Stańczak became co-executive directors; and Etherealize, a new marketing narrative agency led by former researcher Danny Ryan, was established; Meanwhile, EF further restructured its board of directors and clarified its cypherpunk values; By mid-year, the foundation also restructured its R&D department, integrating teams and making personnel adjustments to ensure that core protocol priorities were focused; This series of measures proved effective, significantly strengthening Ethereum's execution capabilities. Especially with the successful implementation of the Fusaka upgrade at the end of the year, just seven months after the Pectra upgrade in May, it demonstrated that EF, despite significant leadership changes, still had the ability to drive major updates, marking Ethereum's entry into an accelerated development pace of "two hard forks per year." Since the network transitioned to PoS through The Merge in September 2022, the Ethereum network has essentially focused on only one major upgrade per year, such as the Shapella upgrade in April 2023 and the Dencun upgrade in March 2024: the former opened staking withdrawals, completing a key step in the PoS transition; the latter launched EIP-4844, officially opening the Blob data channel, significantly reducing L2 costs. In 2025, two important hard fork upgrades, Pectra and Fusaka, were completed. More importantly, 2025 saw the first systematic planning of naming upgrades for the next two years: Glamsterdam and Hegotá. While there's no official written rule, it's interesting that late last year, The Block cited a Consensys source saying that since The Merge, Ethereum researchers aimed for a major upgrade every year, but now they are planning to "accelerate the pace of hard forks, switching to once every six months," and explicitly stated that Fusaka initiated Ethereum's twice-yearly upgrade cycle. This "institutional" change regarding the upgrade schedule can be considered a milestone. The reason is simple: previously, the release schedule depended more on the development readiness, and for developers and infrastructure, the expected window was unstable, and as those familiar with the industry know, delays were not uncommon. This also means that the successful delivery of the two major upgrades in 2025 validated the feasibility of "upgrades every six months." The systematic planning of two named upgrades (Glamsterdam and Hegotá) in 2026, with priority arrangements around these two nodes across three development tracks, represents a further institutionalization. Theoretically, this is somewhat similar to the release schedule of Apple or Android systems, aiming to reduce uncertainty for developers and potentially bringing three positive impacts: enhanced L2 predictability, such as allowing Rollups to plan parameter adjustments and protocol adaptations in advance; clear wallet and infrastructure adaptation windows, enabling product teams to plan compatibility and feature launches according to schedule; and stable institutional risk assessment cycles, meaning upgrades are no longer unexpected events but a regular engineering practice. This structured rhythm is essentially a manifestation of engineering management and also highlights Ethereum's shift from scientific research to engineering delivery. II. The Three Pillars of Protocol Development in 2026 A closer look at the 2026 protocol priority update plan reveals that EF no longer simply lists scattered EIPs, but reorganizes protocol development into three strategic directions: Scale, Improve UX, and Harden the L1. First is Scale, which merges the original "Scale L1" and "Scale blobs" because EF recognizes that scaling the L1 execution layer and broadening the data availability layer are two sides of the same coin. Therefore, the most eye-catching technology in the upcoming Glamsterdam upgrade in the first half of the year is "Block-level Access Lists," which aims to completely change Ethereum's existing transaction execution model—which can be understood as changing from a "single lane" of sequential processing to a "multi-lane" of parallel processing: Block producers will pre-calculate and mark which transactions can run simultaneously without conflict, and clients can then allocate transactions to multiple CPU cores for parallel processing, thereby greatly improving efficiency; at the same time, ePBS (built-in proposer-builder separation) will also be included in the upgrade, embedding the MEV-Boost process, which currently relies on external relays, into the protocol itself, not only reducing the risk of centralization but also providing validators with a more ample time window to verify ZK proofs. With these underlying optimizations, the race to increase the Gas cap will intensify in 2026. EF has already set a clear goal of "moving towards 100 million and above," with radical proponents even predicting that after ePBS, the Gas cap could double to 200 million or even higher. For L2, increasing the number of blobs is equally crucial, with the number of data blocks per block expected to increase to over 72, supporting hundreds of thousands of transactions per second on the L2 network. Secondly, there's the Improve UX, aiming to eliminate cross-chain barriers and popularize cross-chain interoperability and native account abstraction. As mentioned earlier, EF believes the core of solving L2 fragmentation lies in making Ethereum "feel like a chain again," a vision that relies on the maturity of the intent architecture. For example, the Open Intents Framework, launched by EF in collaboration with multiple teams, is becoming a universal standard. It allows users to simply declare their desired outcome when transferring assets between L2 blockchains, while the underlying solver network performs the complex path calculations. The Ethereum Interoperability Layer (EIL) goes a step further, attempting to build a trustless transport layer, aiming to provide cross-L2 transactions with an experience indistinguishable from single-chain transactions. At the wallet level, native account abstraction will remain a key focus this year. Following the first step with EIP-7702 in Pectra in 2025, EF plans to push for proposals such as EIP-7701 or EIP-8141 in 2026. The ultimate goal is to make every wallet on Ethereum a smart contract wallet by default, completely eliminating complex EOA wallets and additional gas payment intermediaries. Furthermore, the implementation of L1 fast confirmation rules will significantly reduce confirmation time from the current 13-19 minutes to 15-30 seconds. This will directly benefit all cross-chain applications that rely on L1 finality, which is of great significance for cross-chain bridges, stablecoin settlement, and RWA asset trading. Finally, there's Harden the L1, aiming at a trillion-dollar security defense line. This is also due to the increasing value locked in the Ethereum ecosystem, elevating the security resilience of the L1 layer to a strategic level. Regarding censorship resistance, FOCIL (Fork Selective Include List, EIP-7805) is becoming a core solution. It empowers multiple validators to force specific transactions to be included in blocks. Even if block producers attempt to censor, as long as a portion of the network is honest, the user's transaction will eventually be recorded on the chain. Facing the long-term threat of quantum computing, EF established a new post-quantum (PQ) research team at the beginning of the year. Their work in 2026 will focus on researching quantum-resistant signature algorithms and considering how to seamlessly migrate them to the Ethereum mainnet, ensuring the security of billions of dollars in assets in the future is not threatened by quantum algorithm cracking. III. A More "Collaborative" Ethereum is Coming. In general, if one word could summarize Ethereum in 2026, it would be "collaboration." Upgrades will no longer revolve around a single explosive innovation, but rather around the coordinated advancement of three main lines: **Scale** handles throughput and cost; **Improve UX** handles usability and adoption; and **Harden the L1** handles security and neutrality. These three elements together determine whether Ethereum can support the on-chain economy of the next decade. Meanwhile, more noteworthy than the technology roadmap is the strategic shift reflected behind this "three-track" structure. As mentioned above, when the Fusaka upgrade is successfully completed at the end of 2025 and the rhythm of two hard forks per year is established, Ethereum has actually completed a "systematic" leap in its development model. The priority update released in early 2026 further extends this institutionalization to the planning level of technology direction—in the past, Ethereum upgrades often revolved around a "star proposal" (such as EIP-1559, merge, EIP-4844), but now, upgrades are no longer defined by a single proposal, but consist of the coordinated advancement of three tracks. From a broader perspective, 2026 is also a crucial year for the reconstruction of Ethereum's "value narrative." In recent years, market pricing of Ethereum has largely revolved around the "fee increases brought about by L2 scaling." However, with improvements in mainnet performance and the shift of L2's positioning from "sharding" to "trust spectrum," Ethereum's core value is being re-anchored to its irreplaceable position as "the world's most secure settlement layer." What does this mean? Simply put, Ethereum is transforming from a platform reliant on "transaction fee revenue" into an asset anchor reliant on a "security premium." The profound impact of this shift may gradually become apparent in the coming years—when stablecoin issuers, RWA tokenization institutions, and sovereign wealth funds choose their settlement layer, they will not choose the cheapest network, but the most secure one. Ethereum is truly evolving from a "technology testing ground" into an "engineering delivery platform," and the institutionalization of Ethereum protocol governance may truly mature by 2026. And we may be at a peculiar juncture: the underlying technology is becoming increasingly complex (such as parallel execution and the PQ algorithm), but the user experience is becoming increasingly simple. The maturity of account abstraction and intent frameworks is pushing Ethereum towards that ideal endpoint—returning Web3 to user intuition. If this can truly be achieved, Ethereum in 2026 could very well transform from a blockchain testing ground into a global financial foundation capable of supporting trillions of dollars in assets, where users don't need to understand the underlying protocol.

data.title: Detailed teardown of BIP-110 (10,000-word article)
data.description:
In February 2026, the controversial Bitcoin proposal BIP-110 was officially merged into the official BIP proposal repository [1]. This Bitcoin improvement proposal, proposed by developer Dathon Ohm, strongly supported by developer Dash Luke Jr., and promoted by the implementation of the client Bitcoin Knots, aims to prevent the Bitcoin blockchain space from being occupied by non-BTC transactions (i.e., so-called ecosystem applications, such as inscriptions, BRC-20, and other use cases). It has received much attention and debate from the community before and after its inception. This article intends to dissect it to see if some insightful conclusions can be drawn.

I. Core Content of the Proposal:A "Temporary Soft Fork" for Data Storage

BIP-110 is titled "Reduced Data Temporary Softfork," and its core objective is very clear: to temporarily limit the size of data fields at the consensus level to correct the incentive distortion caused by standardization supporting arbitrary data, and to refocus priorities on improving Bitcoin's function as a currency.

Specifically, the proposal stipulates that during the one-year temporary deployment period, blocks must comply with the following additional rules: (1) Script public key (scriptPubKey) length limit: Newly created output script public keys exceeding 34 bytes are invalid, unless the first opcode is OP_RETURN (in which case a maximum of 83 bytes is allowed). This means that, except for explicitly discardable outputs like OP_RETURN, the core identifiers of all UTXOs must be simplified. (2) Data push and witness element size limit: Data pushed by OP_PUSHDATA* series opcodes and witness stack elements exceeding 256 bytes are invalid (except for redeemScript in BIP16). This directly targets the practice of embedding large blocks of data into transactions, such as inscriptions. (3) Undefined Witness Versions Disabled: Spending undefined witness versions (i.e., non-Witness v0/BIP 141, Taproot/BIP 341, or P2A) is considered invalid. While creating such outputs is still allowed, they cannot be spent within the next year. (4) Taproot Annexes Disabled: Witness stacks containing Taproot annexes are considered invalid. Annexes, as undefined data fields reserved for future upgrades, are currently completely blocked. (5) Taproot Control Block Size Limit: Taproot control blocks exceeding 257 bytes (corresponding to a Merkle tree with a maximum of 128 script leaves) are invalid. This limits the script complexity that a single UTXO can support. (6) OP_SUCCESS* opcodes disabled: OP_SUCCESS* opcodes in Tapscript (whether executed or not) are invalid. These opcodes are also reserved for future upgrades. (7) Conditional opcodes disabled: OP_IF or OP_NOTIF instructions in Tapscript (regardless of the result) are invalid. This directly combats the use of conditional statements to hide data. It is worth noting that UTXOs created before the activation height are not subject to the new rules when spent. After the one-year period of the soft fork, all UTXOs will return to an unrestricted state.

II. Motivation of the Proposal: Combating “Data Abuse” and Defending the “Essence of Money”

The motivation section of BIP-110 is strongly worded, reflecting the proposer’s fundamental rejection of so-called “data embedding” behavior. Its core logic can be summarized as follows:

(1) Continuation of Historical Tradition

The proposal points out that the Bitcoin community has historically treated the technology of embedding arbitrary data into Bitcoin transactions with an “adversarial” attitude. This adversarial attitude is seen as a necessary means to protect Bitcoin as the “native currency of the Internet”.

From the early discussions of OP_RETURN in 2010, to the debate about blockchain size in 2013-2014, and then to the inscription controversy since 2022, this line of thought has always existed.

(2) Incentive Distortion and Negative Externalities

This is the most convincing technical argument of the proposal. The proposal argues that fee markets cannot properly solve the incentive problem of data storage:

- Payment Transaction: Payers pay miners a one-time fee to obtain a one-time settlement service. After the miners complete the service, node operators voluntarily maintain the historical ledger because it is the basis for Bitcoin's operation as a currency.

- Data Storage Transaction: Payers only pay a one-time fee to the miners who contain the data, but the burden of storing the data permanently falls on all node operators.

Node operators never receive any fee sharing, yet they are forced to download, store, and provide this data indefinitely. This asymmetric incentive results in miners profiting while nodes bear the costs, objectively encouraging data embedding behavior and undermining network decentralization. (3) Response to emerging trends such as "inscriptions" The proposal explicitly mentions the "inscription" technology (i.e., Ordinals) that began to be "exploited" in 2022, arguing that it creates "significantly unnecessary burdens on node operators" and shifts the development focus—from Bitcoin's fundamental purpose as a "sound, permissionless, borderless currency" to supporting non-monetary use cases. (4) Protecting Payment Use Cases and Censorship Resistance The proposal argues that data storage and payments unfairly compete for block space, driving up Bitcoin payment costs and forcing people to rely on third-party payment processors, thus making Bitcoin payments more susceptible to censorship. By limiting data storage, payment costs can be reduced and censorship resistance enhanced. (5) Maintaining Low-Cost Node Operations Maintaining a low barrier to entry for running nodes (whether in terms of financial or other costs) has always been a core promise of Bitcoin's decentralization. Limiting the expansion of UTXO sets and the unlimited growth of block data directly serves this goal.

III. Technical Details of the Proposal:A Carefully Designed "Containment" Strategy

The technical design of BIP-110 embodies the idea of ​​"minimal intervention, maximum effect," attempting to block the main data embedding pathways while minimizing impact on known currency use cases.

(1) Why limit the script public key to 34 bytes?

The script public key in the UTXO set must be stored in a fast medium (usually RAM), which is far more expensive than slow storage. Modern Bitcoin practice has moved all spending conditions to the witness, and the script public key only needs to commit to these conditions with a hash value, so 34 bytes is sufficient.

Large script public keys not only waste space, but can also be used to create "poisoned blocks" (maliciously crafted blocks with extremely long verification times). Limiting them has almost no impact on existing practices.

(2) Why retain OP_RETURN?

OP_RETURN output has been proven to be unspendable, and nodes do not need to store it in the UTXO set. Historically, a maximum of 83 bytes was tolerated simply to avoid garbage data flooding other types of output scripts. Although pay-to-contract and Taproot techniques can replace the functionality of OP_RETURN, the proposal retains this option to avoid breaking legacy protocols.

(3) Why limit the data size to 256/257 bytes?

256 bytes is sufficient for legitimate cryptographic uses (such as large number arithmetic). More importantly, with modern compression techniques, 300-400 bytes can represent an image. The proposer believes that images are the most harmful data storage use case, with high demand, leading to high costs, UTXO set expansion, and potentially controversial content. Limiting to 256 bytes can prevent the embedding of large, continuous blocks of data.

(4) Why disable OP_IF/OP_NOTIF?

In the Taproot design, conditions should be evaluated off-chain, with the final execution path only revealed on-chain. Ideally, key path spending should be used to avoid publishing any scripts. OP_IF is not only redundant in Tapscript, but is also often abused to inject "skipped during execution" junk data. While it cannot completely prevent steganography, banning OP_IF almost eliminates a common abuse route for free. (5) Why a temporary soft fork? This is one of the most controversial and ingenious designs in the proposal. The temporary (one year) nature serves several purposes: - Reduce censorship risk: Reassure the community that this is merely an intervention for a specific crisis, rather than a permanent change in the direction of development, thereby reducing resistance to acceptance. - Avoid hindering future upgrades: Some restrictions (such as Taproot tree depth) may be too stringent, but developing a more robust solution takes time. The temporary deployment buys developers a year to design more refined long-term rules. - Provide a market adaptation period: Any potentially affected projects (such as Miniscript, BitVM) can use this year to adjust or migrate. IV. Trade-offs and Risks: The Proposal's Achilles' Heel The authors of BIP-110 are surprisingly candid in the "Trade-offs" section, acknowledging the following potential problems with the proposal: (1) Taproot Control Block Limitation and Smart Contracts Limiting the Taproot control block to 257 bytes (maximum 128 script leaves) could affect advanced smart contracts such as BitVM that rely on large amounts of executable scripts. The proposal acknowledges this as an "unfortunate trade-off" but believes these use cases are still in the early stages of development and can continue to be experimented with on testnets or sidechains over the next year. (2) OP_IF/OP_NOTIF Restrictions and Existing Wallets Some wallet software (such as Miniscript) habitually creates Tapleafs containing OP_IF. The proposal mitigates the risk of fund freezing through "exemption from UTXO created before activation" and "two-week grace period," but cannot completely rule out the theoretical possibility. (3) The “Perfect Storm” of Fund Freezing The proposal details the extreme conditions under which funds may be frozen or lost: all conditions must be met simultaneously—P2TR UTXO, pre-signed transaction, confirmation and spending within a one-year deployment period, selected Tapleaf containing OP_IF or depth > 7, key path unavailable and no other suitable Tapleaf (frozen), or other Tapleaf spent in an unexpected manner (lost). (4) The “Disruption” of Developer Space The proposal frankly admits: “Yes, this proposal is intended to disrupt user space, specifically data storage user space.” This candor may exacerbate the concerns of opponents—if user space can be disrupted today for “anti-spam” purposes, will more use cases be disrupted tomorrow under other pretexts? V. Deployment Mechanism: Radical Political Statement The deployment parameters of BIP-110 are themselves a radical political statement: A 55% hashrate threshold (instead of the usual 95%): If more than 55% of miners' hashrate supports the move within a 2016-block cycle, BIP-110 will automatically launch after two weeks. The authors argue that only permanent consensus changes require 95% hashrate, and this temporary soft fork is urgent, making a lower threshold more ideal. This contrasts sharply with the traditional requirement of "broad consensus" (such as the 95% threshold for Segwit and Taproot). Opponents argue that this violates the spirit of "rough consensus," which seeks broad acceptance. **Note from ChainTeach:** The concept of "rough consensus" was first proposed by the IETF, and its famous principle is: "We reject kings, presidents, and voting. We believe in rough consensus and running code." Traditional understanding of "rough consensus" includes the following key characteristics: 1. Non-voting system – not relying on majority vote, avoiding "tyranny of the majority"; 2. Technology-driven – viewpoints prevail based on technical rationality and security, rather than numbers or influence; 3. Dissent is permissible – opposing opinions are allowed as long as they do not affect the overall ability to act; 4. Code is vote – final consensus is reflected in the actual code executed by nodes; 5. Long-term evolution – consensus formation takes time, not short-term decisions. - Forced signaling period: During a difficulty adjustment period before block height 965664 (approximately September 2026) is locked, miners are forced to signal support; if no explicit support signal is received from miners after this period, BIP-110 is unconditionally launched via UASF (User Activated Soft Fork), treating blocks carrying invalid data as invalid. This further reduces the space for opponents. Note: BIP-110 uses a modified version of the BIP9 signaling mechanism. Specific parameters are as follows: name: reduced_data bit: 4 starttime: 1764547200 (~December 1, 2025) timeout: NO_TIMEOUT min_activation_height: 0 max_activation_height: 965664 (~September 1, 2026)

active_duration: 52416 blocks (~1 year after activation)

threshold: 1109/2016 (55%)

- One-year validity period: After activation, the rule is only effective for approximately one year (52416 blocks), after which it automatically expires.

This deployment mechanism conveys a clear message: the proposer believes the situation is so urgent that it is necessary to bypass the traditional high-threshold consensus process.

As Renaud Cuny said, “After the inscription consumed 37% of the block space and no one took action for three years, the mechanism no longer requested permission.”[2] Opponents may argue that this sets a dangerous precedent—any group with 55% of the computing power could force temporary consensus changes in the future.

VI. Community Controversy:Monetary Purism vs. Protocol Minimalism

BIP-110 touches on the deepest ideological differences in the Bitcoin community:

Main arguments of the supporters:

1. Monetary Purism: The sole purpose of Bitcoin is to become a sound money.

Any non-payment use case is a waste of block space and should be resisted. 2. Node Decentralization First: Controlling the size of the UTXO set and block data expansion is a necessary measure to maintain node decentralization. 3. Incentive Distortion Needs Correction: The incentive mismatch where miners reap rewards while nodes bear costs must be corrected through consensus layer intervention. 4. Precedent and Signal: This proposal sends a clear signal to the market—data storage is undesirable, and development resources should focus on monetary functions. Key points of the opposition: 1. Protocol minimization: The consensus layer should be as simple as possible, enforcing only the minimum rules needed to prevent double-spending. Content filtering should remain at the policy or application layer. 2. The boundaries of "adversarial" approaches: Bitcoin is meant to "defend against censorship," not "defend against specific use cases." Actively excluding certain applications through consensus rules violates the principle of "permissionless." 3. The slippery slope effect: Today we can restrict data for "anti-spam," tomorrow can we restrict transaction amounts for "anti-financial crime"? The day after tomorrow, can we restrict scripts for "anti-immoral content"? 4. Technical Feasibility Questionable: Can the 256-byte limit truly prevent data storage? Circumvention methods such as fragmented storage and steganography still exist. Will disabling OP_IF affect the legitimate construction of complex scripts? 5. Controversy Regarding Program Legality: Does the 55% threshold and mandatory signaling period constitute a "coup" against existing governance processes? Will it be abused in the future? Interestingly, the opponents in this controversy are mostly influential opinion leaders with a larger voice, while the supporters lack figures of comparable stature. For example, OGs (old guards) who have explicitly expressed their opposition to BIP-110 include: - Adam Back, CEO of Blockstream and inventor of hashcash: People spent too much time in Q4 2025 educating others about the architectural limitations of filters. In short, "it's stupid." We can't keep wasting endless time and attention on these bottomless pits. - Casey Rodarmor, inventor of the Ordinal inscription protocol: This is a technically flawed and confiscating proposal that removes important functionality and doesn't even achieve its stated goals. - Wang Chun, co-founder of F2Pool: BIP-110 is not just about limiting the size of OP_RETURN; it's an attempt to package a bunch of nonsense in the name of protecting children and then impose it on us as a whole, like a government censoring social media. - Jameson Lopp, co-founder of Casa, wrote a lengthy critique of BIP-110: BIP-110 is a high-risk and counterproductive governance adventure disguised as "anti-spam." Its low 55% miner threshold and mandatory signaling period greatly increase the risk of chain splits; its forfeit rule changes could freeze existing funds that rely on Taproot functionality; it damages Bitcoin's neutral reputation against censorship without actually preventing data embedding (Peter Todd has demonstrated that the full proposal text can be embedded in compliant transactions); it restricts future innovations like BitVM, and the "temporary" rhetoric is misleading (supporters' real intention is permanent, extreme restrictions). From an economic perspective, miners lack incentives (zero signal rate, reduced transaction fee revenue), node signals lack economic weight (making them susceptible to manipulation by Sybil attacks), and prediction markets show a 98% failure rate. Ultimately, this is merely a culture war waged by a small group of moralistic purists, attempting to forcefully resolve issues that should be handled by the market and strategy layers. It's clear that the opposition represents the elite class within the entire Bitcoin ecosystem. Blockstream is a major supporter of Bitcoin Core, and it's perfectly logical for them to champion the removal of the default data embedding size limit for OP_RETURN in Core V30. Ordinal is a pioneering representative of the so-called "Bitcoin (application) ecosystem." F2Pool is a well-known mining pool and a advocate for miners' interests. Finally, Jameson Lopp is a representative figure of independent developers and Bitcoin applications. Compared to the constellation of prominent opponents, voices explicitly supporting BIP-110 are relatively scarce in search results. This could be due to several reasons: - Supporters are mostly anonymous or technically savvy: the proposal's author, Dathon Ohm, is an anonymous developer, and while Luke Dashjr, a key promoter, has extensive experience in Bitcoin Knots clients, he is not a high-profile figure on social media. - Supporters may prefer to "vote with code": search results indicate that the proportion of Bitcoin Knots nodes supporting BIP-110 is rising—as of February 23, 2026, approximately 7.99% of Bitcoin nodes (1995/24981) have indicated their readiness to support BIP-110. Compared to 2.98% a month ago, support has increased by about 5% in one month. - Silent support from ordinary users in the community: Many long-term Bitcoin holders who have reservations about the inscription ecosystem may emotionally agree with BIP-110's "monetary purism" goals, but are simply unwilling to publicly engage in the debate.

VII. Prelude to History:Similar Situations for Satoshi Nakamoto

TeachChain found three cases related to on-chain data filtering and restrictions that Satoshi Nakamoto participated in discussions about in the early days of Bitcoin:

(1) Before disappearing, Satoshi Nakamoto removed 15 opcodes, completely disabled them, and added a hard limit (520 bytes) to the size of data that could be manipulated on the script engine stack. He did this because, frankly, he messed up—leaving a large number of vulnerabilities that could allow complex scripts to be used to launch denial-of-service attacks against the entire network, create huge and costly transactions to verify, and cause node crashes.

(2) On December 8, 2010, Satoshi Nakamoto released Bitcoin Core version 0.3.18, which included a check called IsStandard() to determine whether transactions conform to standards (submitted by Gavin Andresen), which was met with much skepticism and opposition from the community. For example: Netizen theymos commented: This is meaningless. Why should miners adopt this change? It means they will receive fewer transaction fees because they lose non-standard transactions. He also pointed out that miners have clearly opposed it: ArtForz (which owns more than 15% of the network's computing power), tcatm (2 Ghash/s), and doublec (the mining pool maintainer) have stated that they will not use IsStandard. Therefore, non-standard transactions will still be possible. He also gave a threatening preview of his actions: "When I have time, I will make a patch for Bitcoin to remove all non-network-enforced transaction restrictions so that other miners can easily configure themselves to include these transactions." jgarzik vehemently stated, "Please launch your own blockchain, not fork the network like this. I want you to understand how much damage your forced inclusion of non-monetary data is causing. I never said this would lead to a blockchain fork. This is more fundamental: a rules fork. A forked network means that most miners no longer run the mainstream Bitcoin transaction rules. Theymos seems to be drawing a line, trying to convince most miners to stop focusing on the mainstream Bitcoin transaction verification rules. He has the right to do so. Miners also have the right to verify what they want to verify. But this fork will make working on the network more difficult in the future, and in effect, it opens the door for the blockchain to be filled with all sorts of non-monetary data, as mentioned in other discussions." (3) In December 2010, Satoshi Nakamoto commented on BitDNS, a non-monetary application on the Bitcoin blockchain, as follows: "I think BitDNS could be a completely independent network and an independent blockchain, sharing CPU computing power with Bitcoin. The only overlap would be allowing miners to simultaneously search for proof-of-work for both networks. These networks don't need any coordination. Miners would subscribe to both networks in parallel. They would scan the SHA, so if they found a valid solution, they could potentially solve both networks simultaneously. If one network has a lower difficulty, the solution might only be valid for one network. I think external miners could call getwork from both programs and merge the work. Perhaps first call Bitcoin to get the work, then hand it over to BitDNS's getwork to merge it into a joint work." This isn't fragmentation, but rather a sharing and amplification of the combined CPU power between networks. This solves a problem: if multiple networks exist, they can become mutually threatening when available CPU power is concentrated to attack one of them. Instead, all networks in the world will share combined CPU power, increasing overall strength. This will make it easier for smaller networks to launch by connecting to an existing miner base. Regarding incentives, he added: "The incentive is that you can also earn rewards from additional sidechains for the same work. Why not get free domain names for the same work you're generating Bitcoin? If you're generating 50 BTC per week now, you can now get 50 BTC plus some domain names." You have a job. If you solve it, it will simultaneously solve a block for both Bitcoin and BitDNS. Conceptually, they are connected by a Merkle tree. To commit to Bitcoin, you break the branch of BitDNS; to commit to BitDNS, you break the branch of Bitcoin. In practice, to modify Bitcoin, BitDNS might require about 200 extra bytes, but that's not a big deal. You've been talking about 50 domain names per block; compared to that, spending an extra 200 bytes per block for backward compatibility is negligible. If we really care about saving a few bytes, we could perhaps schedule a block in the distant future where Bitcoin will be upgraded to a more modern architecture with the Merkle tree at the top. Please note that both chains are under this new Merkle tree. This means that Bitcoin and BitDNS each have their own in-chain links within their respective blocks. This is the opposite of the common timestamp server architecture—that architecture places the chain at the top layer, followed by the Merkle tree, because that would create a common parent chain. Here, there are two timestamp servers that do not share the same chain. Clearly, Satoshi Nakamoto's idea was that non-monetary applications like BitDNS should ideally have their own independent chain and not share timestamp services with the Bitcoin main chain (i.e., a PoW chain). This certainly does not mean encouraging BitDNS to embed data into the Bitcoin main chain. VII. Thought Experiment: What would Satoshi Nakamoto think if he were still alive? Based on our understanding of Satoshi Nakamoto's historical statements, he might raise four questions about Bitcoin's non-monetary application ecosystem: (1) Did miners receive additional incentives? Yes (transaction fees), but these were "stolen" from the main chain payment market, not from rewards from external chains. When discussing BitDNS in 2010, Satoshi Nakamoto envisioned a model of "one computing power, multiple rewards, data separation"—miners received both Bitcoin rewards and BitDNS domain name rewards, while the data was stored on a side chain. Inscription's "data embedded in the main chain" model deviates from this vision. (2) Did the data change the core structure of Bitcoin? No (using existing witness fields), but it takes up space that would otherwise be used for payments. This touches on Satoshi Nakamoto's concerns in 2010 when he restricted non-standard transactions: keeping the blockchain focused on transaction records. (3) Is the data valuable? The market's willingness to pay fees indicates that it is valuable to some. But the question is: do payers bear all the social costs? Obviously not—nodes bear the cost of permanent storage. This is a new problem that Satoshi Nakamoto probably didn't have to consider in 2010. (4) Are there negative externalities that the market cannot regulate? Yes, node costs are borne by non-payers. When negative externalities reach a certain scale, is consensus layer intervention necessary? Based on Satoshi Nakamoto's actions back then, it is conceivable that if Satoshi Nakamoto were still alive, he would not have appeased these problems for a long time without taking any action.

VIII. Reflections and Prospects:An Experiment Destined to Be Recorded in History

BIP-110 was eventually merged into the official BIP library, which means that it gained a certain degree of "discussion qualification", but it was far from achieving activation consensus. Its significance may lie more in triggering a profound reflection on the essence of Bitcoin:

(1) Technological Implications

BIP-110 revealed a long-neglected problem: the potential divergence between miner incentives and node incentives.

BIP-110 revealed a long-neglected problem: the potential divergence between miner incentives and node incentives.

Even without considering data storage, this discrepancy exists in ordinary payments—miners collect fees, and nodes store data permanently. It's just that data storage use cases amplify it to a degree that cannot be ignored. More sophisticated mechanisms may be needed in the future to fundamentally address this incentive mismatch. This leads us to further consider that if the Bitcoin blockchain is allowed to expand unchecked, it will significantly raise the barrier to entry for running an unincentivized full node, or user full node, thereby greatly reducing the number of user full nodes. The lack of constraints on user full node verification and block rejection will allow miners to further expand their influence and decision-making power derived from their block-producing rights, thus allowing mining interest groups to seize greater power and pushing Bitcoin towards an oligopoly, ultimately significantly weakening its decentralization. The situation will be exacerbated, especially when a group of maintainers adopts a policy of appeasement and non-resistance towards mining groups exists. Developers and miners, who are in the imagined system of checks and balances, will in fact tend to collude. (2) Impact on governance The proposal of the 55% threshold and mandatory signaling period may become a "template" or "counterexample" for future controversial changes. It forces the community to think: when faced with an "imminent threat", can and should the decision-making process be adjusted? Who has the right to define "urgency"? There are no simple answers to these questions. After studying the chain, we tend to regard BIP-110 as a "riot" launched by the people after the community failed to stop Bitcoin Core maintainers from constantly compromising on the data embedding of non-monetary use cases through off-chain discussions. So, unsurprisingly, this uprising was met with unanimous and strong opposition from vested interests, those in power, and the elite class. In a sense, the more the elites opposed it, the more it proved the grassroots and populist nature of BIP-110. (3) The Divergence of the Bitcoin Ecosystem Regardless of whether BIP-110 is ultimately activated, it has already exacerbated the divergence of the Bitcoin ecosystem. Some developers and users may turn to more "open" protocols (such as other UTXO chains or Layer 2 solutions), while others may more firmly support "monetary purism." The debate between Bitcoin as "digital gold" and "smart contract platform" may intensify. Previously, numerous diverse ideas born from the Bitcoin community, unable to be accommodated by Bitcoin, left and incubated into numerous altcoin blockchains. This included Ethereum, the progenitor of smart contract blockchains. Now, so-called Bitcoin ecosystem applications like BRC-20, as their names suggest, are nothing more than clumsy imitations of Ethereum and its ecosystem (such as ERC-20). This prompts us to ponder: if Bitcoin begins to imitate Ethereum, if Bitcoin loses its long-held pride in its thought leadership, can it still attract the world's top developers to contribute unpaid? After all, the Ethereum Foundation and many other projects pay salaries. (4) Long-term impact on ecosystem applications such as inscriptions Even if BIP-110 is not activated, the opposition it represents will affect market expectations. Ecosystem projects such as inscriptions and BRC-20 that rely on large-block data embedding may need to consider migrating to more suitable infrastructure (such as the Lightning Network, RGB, Taproot Assets, etc., which are true Layer 2), or adjusting their technical solutions to adapt to possible future limitations. When inscription NFTs first appeared in early 2024, ChainChain once praised Casey Rodarmor's idea of ​​integrating rather than separating metadata and media data. This is because a major hidden danger of the Ethereum ERC-721 NFT standard is that metadata is on-chain, while media data such as images are off-chain, which is heavily dependent on centralized infrastructure. This has created a rift in the "ownership" that the NFT industry has always claimed, and even, to put it more seriously, has made it a joke due to the nature of centralized control. The Inscription concept repairs this. This is what ChainCall praises. However, as the discussion deepens, we can further realize that the most suitable carrier for maintaining the integration of Inscription might be an independent sidechain, rather than embedding it into or parasitizing the Bitcoin chain through special means. Following Satoshi Nakamoto's idea, this independent sidechain could allow Bitcoin miners to contribute blocks to it through joint mining, so that miners could simultaneously enjoy incentives from both the Bitcoin chain and the Inscription chain, while the Inscription data would not pollute the Bitcoin chain. (5) The final evaluation rests with time. The authors of BIP-110 designed the proposal as temporary, perhaps hoping that time would test its rationality. A year later, if data storage really "poisons" the network, leading to a sharp decrease in the number of nodes or high fees, BIP-110 may be regarded as a "prophet who saved Bitcoin". Conversely, if Bitcoin still functions well without BIP-110, and the inscription ecosystem brings unexpected innovation and adoption, then BIP-110 may be remembered as an "overreaction panic". ChainChain believes that regardless of whether BIP-110 will ultimately win, it will inevitably have a natural sense of justice, progressiveness and revolutionary nature in the historical process because of its bottom-up intention to break the existing power structure and interest structure. The historical cycle is inescapable. Any system capable of transcending cycles must be able to internally disrupt power structures and interest groups. Only when power and wealth are perpetual can a system be perpetual. The newly rich OGs must be constantly overthrown by the impoverished grassroots for civilization to continuously renew and continue. Otherwise, the system and civilization will only succumb to corruption and extinction under the constant drain of social stratification. This is the philosophical essence of "popular uprisings, rebellion is justified." Regardless of the outcome, BIP-110 has added a significant chapter to the history of Bitcoin. It reminds us that Bitcoin is not just code, but a social experiment shaped by countless participants. In the clash between technology and ideology, the ultimate victor will be the wisdom that can balance innovation and stability, freedom and responsibility.

data.title: The US has seized over $30 billion in cryptocurrency assets, with the Chen Zhi case accounting for 50%.
data.description: Currently, virtual currencies have already exerted a structural influence on the international financial and monetary systems. However, due to their technological characteristics and regulatory gaps, they have also become a major target for cybercrime and a new arena for financial competition. A report jointly released on February 26, 2026, by the China National Computer Virus Emergency Response Center and other departments, titled "Ready Player One: An In-Depth Analysis of the Global Virtual Currency Asset Harvesting Operation Under US Technological Hegemony" (hereinafter referred to as the "Report"), shows that, according to incomplete statistics, from 2022 to 2025, the United States has confiscated over $30 billion worth of global virtual currency assets through various cases. "In the digital age, virtual assets have become an indispensable financial asset, and also an object of strong regulation and competition among major powers," said a financial researcher. Domestically, virtual currencies do not have the same legal status as legal tender. On February 6, 2026, the People's Bank of China and eight other departments issued the "Notice on Further Preventing and Handling Risks Related to Virtual Currencies" (hereinafter referred to as the "Notice"), which states that virtual currency-related business activities are illegal financial activities. "Currently, countries such as Singapore and the United States have recognized the legality of virtual currencies. Investors who have trade relations with countries that have legalized virtual currencies, or who legally hold foreign exchange, can invest in these countries through legal means. However, it should be noted that even if investment is legal in these countries, the realization and trading of virtual currencies within China are still illegal," Tang Chunlin, a senior lawyer in the financial field, told Caixin. "Therefore, it is clear that if domestic investors invest in virtual currencies and derivatives and violate laws or public order and good morals, the relevant civil legal acts are invalid, and the resulting losses must be borne by the investors themselves," Yang Xiang, a PhD in Law from Tsinghua University and a lawyer at Beijing Hongfan Law Firm, told Caixin. He added that if investors have overseas businesses, they must examine whether the platform possesses compliance licenses in mainstream legal jurisdictions before participating in virtual currencies. In Yang Xiang's view, the biggest legal risk in virtual currencies is not "holding" them, but rather violating money laundering (offshore) or concealing/disguising the proceeds of crime (domestic) during the "deposit and withdrawal" process. Therefore, it is essential to retain original legal source proof for every transaction (such as salary, dividends, or property sales certificates). Under the penetrating supervision of 2026, only assets with a complete chain of evidence are considered "real assets." The report shows that, according to incomplete statistics, from 2022 to 2025, the United States has confiscated over $30 billion worth of virtual currency assets globally through various cases. The Chen Zhi case alone accounted for $15 billion in confiscated assets, representing 50% of the total. The report states, “The United States’ use of technological hegemony to seize global virtual assets is essentially aimed at maintaining its economic hegemony and the status of the US dollar. On the one hand, it directly plunders global wealth through confiscation and fines to supplement its domestic economic strength; on the other hand, by controlling the regulatory rules and transaction flows of virtual assets, it integrates the digital financial system into the dollar-dominated global financial framework, curbing other countries’ attempts to bypass the dollar through virtual currency assets for settlement.” Four months ago, in October 2025, the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Eastern District of New York announced criminal charges against Chen Zhi, founder of the Prince Group in Cambodia, on charges including wire fraud and money laundering. Simultaneously, it announced the confiscation of approximately 127,000 Bitcoins under his control, valued at approximately $15 billion at the time, setting a record for the largest virtual asset confiscation in U.S. judicial history. In November 2025, the National Computer Virus Emergency Response Center pointed out that a U.S. national-level hacking group had precisely cracked the underlying encryption vulnerability, attacking the LuBian mining pool (belonging to the Prince Group) cold wallet and transferring assets, demonstrating the U.S.'s mature national-level virtual currency asset theft capabilities. This clearly contradicts the U.S. government's claim that "Bitcoin has never been hacked," or its true meaning may be that "Bitcoin has never been hacked by hackers outside the U.S. government." In another case, from 2023 to 2025, the United States pursued both civil and criminal charges against Binance, a renowned international cryptocurrency exchange, and its founder, Changpeng Zhao. The case ultimately ended with Binance paying a $4.35 billion fine (including $2.7 billion in forfeiture of illegal gains, $1.35 billion in civil penalties, and $150 million in personal fines), and Changpeng Zhao signing a plea agreement and being pardoned. The report states that during the investigation, the United States employed comprehensive technical monitoring methods to achieve complete penetration and evidence collection of Binance's operational, user, and transaction data, demonstrating its technological advantages in the field of digital asset platform monitoring. For example, regarding cross-border data theft and internal information acquisition, the United States used hacking techniques to penetrate Binance's internal servers, obtaining core operational data and executive communication records, proving that Binance executives were aware of US regulatory rules but deliberately circumvented compliance requirements. Regarding full-scale monitoring and analysis of transaction data, the report shows that by accessing global blockchain nodes and collaborating with on-chain data analysis companies, the United States has achieved real-time monitoring of Binance's transaction data, accurately locating the trading behavior of US users and the flow of funds to sanctioned regions. Data shows that while US users once accounted for nearly 20% of Binance's user base, only 30%-40% of users completed real-name authentication, which the US used as core evidence of violations. Furthermore, the US technical team conducted penetration tests on Binance's real-name authentication system and anti-money laundering monitoring system, discovering systemic flaws in its compliance mechanisms. Virtual assets are a new type of wealth carrier in the digital age, experiencing rapid development in recent years. According to statistics from CoinGecko (a well-known cryptocurrency tracking and research institution), as of the end of January 2026, the total market capitalization of global virtual currency assets was approximately US$2.73 trillion, of which Bitcoin's total market capitalization reached approximately US$1.57 trillion. Meanwhile, the value of gold reserves held by central banks around the world was approximately $5.83 trillion. This means that the market capitalization of virtual currency assets has reached about 47% of the total market capitalization of global official gold reserves, approaching half, making it a new type of financial asset that cannot be ignored. How can investors hedge against risks? Since 2021, speculative activities related to virtual currencies and RWA (Real-World Asset) tokenization have occurred frequently. These activities have been identified by Chinese financial regulators as significant acts disrupting economic and financial order. On February 6, 2026, the People's Bank of China and other departments clarified the essential nature of virtual currencies, the tokenization of real-world assets, and related business activities: All virtual currency-related business activities conducted within China, including the exchange of legal tender for virtual currencies, the exchange of virtual currencies among themselves, acting as a central counterparty in buying and selling virtual currencies, providing information intermediary and pricing services for virtual currency transactions, token issuance financing, and trading of virtual currency-related financial products, as well as illegal financial activities such as the illegal issuance of token vouchers, unauthorized public issuance of securities, illegal operation of securities and futures businesses, and illegal fundraising, are strictly prohibited and will be resolutely banned according to law. "Conducting real-world asset tokenization activities within China, as well as providing related intermediary and information technology services, which are suspected of involving illegal issuance of tokenized securities, unauthorized public offerings of securities, illegal operation of securities and futures businesses, illegal fundraising, and other illegal financial activities, should be prohibited; except for related business activities conducted based on specific financial infrastructure with the approval of the competent business authorities in accordance with laws and regulations. Foreign entities and individuals are prohibited from illegally providing real-world asset tokenization-related services to domestic entities in any form," the aforementioned "Notice" also stated. However, the "Notice" also opened the floodgates for RWA tokenization activities: Domestic entities directly or indirectly engaging in real-world asset tokenization in the form of foreign debt overseas, or conducting asset securitization or equity-based real-world asset tokenization overseas based on domestic asset ownership, income rights, etc. (hereinafter collectively referred to as domestic equity), should be strictly regulated by the National Development and Reform Commission, the China Securities Regulatory Commission, the State Administration of Foreign Exchange, and other relevant departments according to their respective responsibilities, following the principle of "same business, same risk, same rules." Tang Chunlin reminded that virtual currencies do not have the attributes of legal currency in China, nor are they legal financial investment tools. Furthermore, there is currently no indication that China will loosen regulations in this area or gradually recognize the legality of virtual currencies. Therefore, all virtual currency investment activities conducted within China are illegal investment activities, and investors should be highly vigilant. According to Yang Xiang, many projects claiming to tokenize RWA assets such as real estate and gold are often classified as illegal securities issuance or illegal fundraising in China. Investors participating in such projects are highly susceptible to falling into Ponzi schemes, and the authenticity of the assets is difficult to trace. "Investors with overseas business or compliant overseas status who want to participate in virtual currencies must conduct thorough compliance due diligence. When it comes to cross-border operations or overseas asset allocation, they must examine whether the platform possesses compliant licenses in mainstream jurisdictions, such as a Virtual Asset Service Provider license in Hong Kong or an MPI license (a high-level payment institution license issued by the Monetary Authority of Singapore) in Singapore. At the same time, they should avoid participating in stablecoin transactions pegged to the RMB, which is currently a no-go zone for domestic regulation," Yang Xiang stated.

data.title: Token goes global: Selling Chinese electricity to the world
data.description:
Author:Black Lobster｜Deep Tide TechFlow

In the summer of 1858, a copper-core cable traversed the Atlantic Ocean, connecting London and New York.

The significance of this event was never about the transmission speed, but about the power structure. Whoever laid the undersea cable could profit from the flow of information. The British Empire, relying on this global telegraph network, held the intelligence of its colonies, cotton prices, and war news in its hands.

The empire's strength lay not only in its fleet, but also in that cable.

More than 160 years later, this logic is repeating itself in an unexpected way. In 2026, large-scale Chinese models are quietly devouring the global developer market. Latest data from OpenRouter shows that Chinese models account for 61% of the token consumption of the platform's top ten models, with the top three all originating from China. API requests sent daily by developers in San Francisco, Berlin, and Singapore are traveling across the Pacific Ocean via undersea cables to data centers in China, where computing power is consumed, electricity flows, and results are transmitted back. Electricity never leaves the Chinese power grid, but its value is delivered across borders through tokens. On February 24, 2026, OpenRouter released weekly data: the total token consumption of the platform's top ten models was approximately 8.7 trillion, with Chinese models accounting for 5.3 trillion, or 61%. MiniMax M2.5 debuted at the top with 2.45 trillion tokens, followed by Kimi K2.5 and Zhipu GLM-5. The top three were all from China. This was no accident; a single spark ignited everything. At the beginning of this year, OpenClaw emerged, an open-source tool that truly enabled AI to "do work," capable of directly controlling computers, executing commands, and completing complex workflows in parallel. Within weeks, its GitHub stars surpassed 210,000. John, a finance professional, immediately installed OpenClaw and integrated it with the Anthropic API. He began automatically monitoring stock market information and providing timely trading signals. A few hours later, he stared at his account balance for a few seconds, stunned: tens of dollars gone. This is the new reality brought about by OpenClaw. In the past, chatting with AI involved thousands of tokens per conversation, with negligible costs. After integrating OpenClaw, the AI ​​runs a dozen subtasks simultaneously in the background, repeatedly calling the context and iterating in loops. Token consumption is not linear, but exponential. The bills are like a car with its hood open accelerating, the fuel gauge dropping, and it just won't stop. A clever trick quickly circulated within the developer community: using OAuth tokens to directly connect Anthropic or Google subscription accounts to OpenClaw, turning the monthly "unlimited" credits into free fuel for the AI ​​Agent. This was a method adopted by many developers. Official countermeasures followed. On February 19th, Anthropic updated its agreement, explicitly prohibiting the use of Claude subscription credentials for third-party tools like OpenClaw. Access to Claude functionality required using the API billing channel. Google went even further, extensively blocking subscription accounts that accessed Antigravity and Gemini AI Ultra through OpenClaw. "The world has suffered under Qin rule for too long," John immediately embraced domestically developed large-scale models. On OpenRouter, the domestically developed MiniMax M2.5 model scored 80.2% on software engineering tasks, while Claude Opus 4.6 scored 80.8%, a negligible difference. However, the prices were vastly different: the former cost $0.3 per million tokens of input, while the latter cost $5, a difference of approximately 17 times. John switched over, the workflow continued, and the bill shrank by an order of magnitude; this migration is happening simultaneously worldwide. OpenRouter's COO, Chris Clark, put it bluntly: The reason Chinese open-source models have captured a large market share is because they account for an exceptionally high percentage of proxy workflows run by US developers. To understand the essence of token globalization, one must first understand the cost structure of a token. It seems lightweight; one token is roughly equivalent to 0.75 English words, and a typical conversation with AI consumes only a few thousand tokens. But when these tokens are stacked in trillions, the underlying physical reality becomes incredibly heavy. Breaking down the cost of tokens, there are only two core components: computing power and electricity. Computing power is the depreciation and amortization of GPUs. If you buy an Nvidia H100 for about $30,000, its lifespan, calculated over each inference iteration, is the depreciation cost. Electricity is the fuel that keeps data centers running. A GPU at full load consumes about 700 watts of power. Adding the cost of the cooling system, the electricity bill for a large AI data center can easily exceed hundreds of millions of dollars annually. Now, let's map this physical process. An American developer in San Francisco makes an API request. Data travels from California, via a Pacific undersea fiber optic cable, to a data center in China. The GPU clusters begin operating, electricity flows from China's power grid to the chips, inference is completed, and the results are sent back. The entire process may only take a second or two. Electricity never leaves China's power grid, but its value is delivered across borders through tokens. Herein lies a magical aspect unattainable by ordinary trade: tokens have no physical form, do not pass through customs, are not subject to tariffs, and are not even included in any current trade statistics. China exports a large amount of computing power and electricity services, but this is almost invisible in official commodity trade data. Tokens become a derivative of electricity; the export of tokens is essentially the export of electricity. This is also thanks to China's relatively low electricity prices, which are about 40% lower than those in the United States. This is a physical cost difference that competitors can easily replicate. Furthermore, China's large-scale AI models also have algorithmic and "involution" advantages. DeepSeek V3's MoE architecture allows only a subset of parameters to be activated during inference. Independent tests show that its inference cost is about 36 times lower than GPT-4o, and MiniMax M2.5 also has 229 bytes of total parameters but only activates 10 bytes. The top layer is involution, with over a dozen companies like Alibaba, ByteDance, Baidu, Tencent, Lunar Dark Side, Zhipu, and MiniMax trampling each other on the same track. Prices have long since fallen below reasonable profit margins, and operating at a loss to gain market share has become the norm. Looking closer, this is similar to the "Made in China" export strategy, leveraging supply chain advantages and industry involution to drive down token prices. From Bitcoin to Tokens Before tokens, there was another instance of electricity export. Around 2015, power plant managers in Sichuan, Yunnan, and Xinjiang began receiving a group of strange visitors. These people rented abandoned factories, filled them with densely packed machines, and ran them 24/7. The machines produced nothing; they simply kept solving a mathematical problem, and occasionally, from this endless mathematical problem, they would calculate a Bitcoin. This was the first generation of electricity going global: cheap hydropower and wind power, through the hash calculations of mining machines, were converted into globally circulating digital assets, and then converted into US dollars on exchanges. Electricity didn't cross any borders, but the value of electricity, carried by Bitcoin, flowed to the global market. In those years, China's computing power once accounted for more than 70% of the global Bitcoin mining computing power. China's hydropower and coal-fired power, in this roundabout way, participated in a global redistribution of capital. In 2021, all of this came to an abrupt end. Regulatory hammer fell, miners scattered, and computing power migrated to Kazakhstan, Texas, and Canada. But the underlying logic never disappeared; it was just waiting for a new shell. Until ChatGPT emerged, large-scale models emerged, and former Bitcoin mining farms transformed into AI data centers, mining machines became computing GPUs, and the Bitcoins produced became tokens. The only thing that remained unchanged was electricity. Bitcoin's overseas expansion and token's overseas expansion are isomorphic in their underlying logic, but tokens currently have greater commercial value. Mining is purely mathematical computation; the resulting Bitcoin is a financial asset whose value comes from scarcity and market consensus, and has nothing to do with "what was calculated."
