Computational power itself is not productive; it's more like a byproduct of a trust mechanism. Large-scale model inference is different. GPUs consume electricity but produce real cognitive services: code, analysis, translation, and creativity. The value of a token comes directly from its utility to the user. This is a deeper embedding; once a developer's workflow relies on a particular model, the cost of switching increases over time. Of course, there's another crucial difference: Bitcoin mining was driven out of China, while token globalization was actively chosen by global developers. The Token Wars The submarine cable laid in 1858 represented the British Empire's sovereignty over the information superhighway; whoever owns the infrastructure can define the rules of the game. Token going global is also an undeclared war, fraught with obstacles. Data sovereignty is the first barrier. An API request from an American developer is processed through a Chinese data center, physically passing through China. This isn't a problem for individual developers and small applications, but it's a major weakness in scenarios involving sensitive corporate data, financial information, and government compliance. This is why the Chinese model has the highest penetration rate in development tools and personal applications, but almost no presence in core enterprise systems. The chip ban is the second wall; China's AI development faces export controls on Nvidia's high-end GPUs. The MoE architecture and algorithm optimization can only partially offset this disadvantage; the ceiling remains. However, the current obstacles are just the prologue; a larger battlefield is taking shape. Tokens and AI models have become a new dimension of strategic competition between China and the US, no less significant than the semiconductor and internet competitions of the 20th century, and even closer to an older metaphor: a space race. In 1957, the Soviet Union launched Sputnik 1, shocking the United States and prompting the launch of the Apollo program, which poured resources equivalent to hundreds of billions of dollars today into the space race. The logic of the AI ​​race is strikingly similar, but the intensity will far surpass that of the space race. Space is, after all, a physical space, imperceptible to ordinary people; AI, however, permeates the capillaries of the economy. Behind every line of code, every contract, and every government decision-making system, there may be a large-scale model running for a particular country. Whoever's model becomes the default infrastructure option for global developers gains a structural influence on the global digital economy. This is precisely what makes Washington truly uneasy about the overseas expansion of Chinese tokens. When a developer's codebase, agent workflow, and product logic are all built around an API based on a certain Chinese model, the migration cost will increase exponentially over time. At that point, even if the US legislates restrictions, developers will resist with their feet, just as no programmer can abandon GitHub today. Today's token going global may only be the beginning of this long game. The Chinese model doesn't claim to be disrupting anything; it's simply delivering services to every developer worldwide with an API key at a lower price. This time, the cables are being laid by engineering teams writing code in Hangzhou, Beijing, and Shanghai, and GPU clusters operating day and night in a southern province. This battle for supremacy has no countdown; it takes place 24 hours a day, every day. The unit is tokens, and the battlefield is every developer's terminal.

data.title: Is Circle, whose stock price surged 30% in a single day, quietly becoming the "Visa on the blockchain"?
data.description:
Author: Michael Mach Source: X, @1912212eth

A single quarter's settlement of $11.9 trillion: USDC's size is approaching half of the US GDP.

On February 25th, Circle announced its total revenue and reserve income for fiscal year 2025 at $2.7 billion, a 64% increase. After the announcement, CRCL surged from $61 to $83, marking its largest single-day gain since October 2nd of last year. The market voted with real money, acknowledging the significance of this financial report.

It's worth noting that after reaching a high of $298 following its IPO last June, CRCL's stock price steadily declined, even falling to a historic low of $49.90 on February 5th. This strong rebound is, to some extent, a correction of the market's previously excessive pessimism.

... USDC's circulating supply reached $75.3 billion by the end of 2025, a year-on-year increase of 72%. Let's look at the most crucial metric: USDC's circulating supply reached $75.3 billion by the end of the year, a year-on-year increase of 72%. What does this figure mean? Against the backdrop of a slowdown in the overall stablecoin market, Circle's market share actually expanded by 4.26 percentage points, reaching 28%. The logic behind this shift is simple—Tether's compliance controversies gave USDC an opportunity, while Circle's long-term investment in regulatory compliance is translating into market share. On-chain USDC trading volume reached $11.9 trillion in Q4, a staggering 247% year-over-year increase. This figure is almost half of the US GDP. While there is significant arbitrage and wash trading involved in on-chain transactions, the 247% growth rate still demonstrates the rapid increase in USDC's penetration as a settlement infrastructure. On the revenue side, total revenue in Q4 reached $770 million, a 77% year-over-year increase, exceeding the average analyst expectation of $748 million from FactSet. Reserve income reached $733 million, a 69% year-over-year increase, contributing the vast majority of revenue. Here's an explanation of the reserve income logic: Circle uses user-deposited USD to purchase low-risk assets such as short-term US Treasury bonds, earning interest rate differentials. The reserve return rate in Q4 was 3.8%, a 68 basis point decrease year-over-year, but the doubling of USDC circulation completely offset the impact of declining interest rates. What truly excited the market was the explosive growth in profits. Adjusted EBITDA reached $167 million, a staggering 412% year-over-year increase, far exceeding analysts' expectations of $130 million. The RLDC profit margin (revenue minus distribution costs) jumped from 30% to 40%, a full 10 percentage points increase. Economies of scale are beginning to emerge; the marginal cost of issuing one more USDC is rapidly decreasing. The financial report reveals several noteworthy business signals. First, there's the progress of the Arc public testnet. Over 100 institutions participated, achieving nearly 100% uptime, 0.5-second transaction finality, and an average of 2.3 million transactions per day. These figures may seem like technical parameters, but they reflect the real demand for on-chain settlement from traditional financial infrastructure. Visa announced that US issuers and acquirers can use USDC to settle with Visa, signifying USDC's penetration into the underlying layers of the traditional payment system. It's also worth mentioning that Circle mentioned in its report plans to launch the Arc mainnet within 2026. Secondly, there's the expansion of the Circle Payment Network (CPN). 55 financial institutions have registered, with an annualized transaction volume of $5.7 billion. This figure is still small, but the direction is crucial—Circle is transforming from a simple stablecoin issuer into a payment network operator; the potential of this business model is far greater than simply collecting interest spreads. Regarding the Euro stablecoin EURC, its circulating supply reached €310 million, a year-on-year increase of 284%. Demand for Euro stablecoins is being activated following the implementation of the MiCA regulatory framework. USYC (tokenized US Treasury bonds) assets reached $1.5 billion, a quarter-on-quarter increase of 111%, indicating increased institutional acceptance of on-chain yield products. The financial report wasn't all good news. For the full year, Circle recorded a net loss of $69.5 million, primarily due to $424 million in equity incentive expenses triggered by its IPO. Excluding these non-cash expenses, the full-year adjusted EBITDA was $582 million, a year-on-year increase of 104%. The reserve return rate has fallen from 4.1% to 3.8%, and this trend is likely to continue. According to the latest data from Polymarket, the probability of the Federal Reserve not cutting interest rates was 97% in March, 86% in April, and 46% in June. If the Federal Reserve chooses to cut rates again in June, Circle's interest rate spread income will inevitably be under pressure. The management's guidance for 2026 also reflects this—the revenue margin guidance, excluding distribution costs, is 38%-40%, essentially maintaining the status quo, indicating that the room for profit margin expansion may already be limited.

data.title: Samsung Galaxy S26 Launches Its First “Agentic AI Phone.” What Does That Mean?
data.description:
Samsung has unveiled the Galaxy S26 lineup, marketing it as the world’s first “agentic AI phone,” a device designed not just to answer prompts but to execute multi-step actions across apps on a user’s behalf.

At launch, Samsung is positioning the S26 as a turning point for mobile artificial intelligence — moving beyond reactive assistants toward proactive software agents capable of navigating apps, synthesizing information and completing tasks with minimal input.

Gemini-powered agent takes control across apps

At the center of the Galaxy S26 is a new implementation of Google’s Gemini, designed to function as an operating-level AI agent.

Samsung announced that Galaxy AI will expand with multi-agent support and Perplexity integration on the upcoming S26 series. The update aims to enhance contextual understanding, real-time information retrieval, and smarter on-device AI experiences ahead of Galaxy Unpacked 2026. pic.twitter.com/Fz2XHDl6cU

— EverImagineTech (@EverImagineTech) February 22, 2026

Rather than waiting for a command and returning a response, Gemini can open apps in background windows, move through interfaces and assemble multi-step workflows while the user continues using the phone.

During the product demonstration, Gemini parsed a busy family group chat discussing pizza orders, identified each person’s preferences, opened a food delivery app, built the cart and prepared checkout while waiitng for the user to give the final confirmation.

Hence the baseline is that the system does not complete payments without your final confirmation, maintaining a manual approval safeguard. At launch, the feature supports a limited list of major apps including food delivery, ride-hailing and retail platforms, rolling out first in the United States and South Korea as a preview release.

The shift is significant. For more than a decade, mobile AI assistants have largely been query-response tools. Samsung is now attempting to embed autonomous task execution directly into the smartphone operating layer, eliminating the need for repeated taps, app switching or voice commands.

Multi-agent intelligence and AI-embedded hardware

The Galaxy S26 does not rely on a single AI engine. Samsung is layering multiple agents to create what it describes as a collaborative AI stack. Alongside Gemini, the company has integrated Perplexity as a system-level research assistant capable of scanning open browser tabs and recent activity to synthesize answers without manual navigation.

Galaxy S26からPerplexityをデフォルトAIに？この動きが示す重要なビジネス教訓について考えてみました。

— 池田 朋弘 | ChatGPT最強の仕事術4万部突破！ (@pop_ikeda) June 10, 2025

Meanwhile, Bixby — Samsung’s long-standing assistant — has been rebuilt with contextual awareness. The assistant can interpret conversational cues such as eye strain and immediately surface relevant settings, or provide real-time information without redirecting users into separate apps.

Additional agent-driven features extend across the device. For example, “now brief” proactively compiles daily schedules and surfaced reservations, even from notification history; while "call screening” summarizes unknown callers before users answer.

The AI integration extends into imaging. The S26 Ultra supports 8K video recording using a new APV codec designed for near-lossless quality retention during editing.

The camera quality and the AI features of this Samsung Galaxy S26 Ultra is unmatched chale 👌💥#GalaxyUnpacked#WithGalaxy#SamsungGHpic.twitter.com/YzDZQITZwy

— Fabulous❤️ (@KingFabulo) February 25, 2026

New features like “photo assist” allows users to generate missing visual elements through text prompts, while AI-driven image signal processing enhances selfies and improves low-light video clarity. The computational photography pipeline is tightly coupled with the device’s hardware architecture.

Samsung stakes early claim in the agentic AI race

Samsung’s move comes amid intensifying competition in mobile AI. While Apple has signaled upgrades to Siri and Google’s Pixel devices are expected to integrate similar Gemini capabilities, Samsung is first to broadly commercialize what it calls an “agentic” framework at scale.

The company is also positioning the S26 as proof that smartphones — rather than standalone AI gadgets — remain the natural home for advanced autonomous software. Recent AI hardware launches attempted to replace or supplement phones but struggled to deliver meaningful adoption.

Whether the “agentic AI phone” label endures will depend on how quickly Samsung expands app support and how reliably its agents execute complex tasks. But with the Galaxy S26, the company has made a clear assertion: the future of mobile computing is not just conversational AI — it is AI that acts.

The founder of Ethereum is currently reshaping his financial stake in the ecosystem he helped create.

Vitalik Buterin has moved a substantial portion of his personal ETH holdings throughout February 2026, a move that coincides with a broader strategic shift for the Ethereum Foundation.

While the market often reacts with nerves when a founder sells, this particular sequence of transactions appears to be a calculated effort to fund a leaner, more focused future for the network.

By shifting from his original 700,000 ETH down to approximately 224,000 ETH over the years, Buterin is increasingly positioning himself as a participant rather than just a majority holder.

How Much ETH Did Vitalik Buterin Actually Sell

Recent on-chain data from Arkham and Lookonchain reveals that the scale of these sales has slightly exceeded initial expectations.

While Buterin originally disclosed a plan to withdraw 16,384 ETH on 30 January 2025, the total has since climbed to 17,196 ETH.

The move aligns with the Ethereum Foundation’s “mild austerity” strategy - redirecting funds toward security, privacy, core R&D, and long-term ecosystem… https://t.co/Xqa3KIv1FHpic.twitter.com/8pVroM76ZZ

— Onchain Lens (@OnchainLens) February 26, 2026

This represents a 4.9% increase over the intended target, with the total value of these transactions reaching roughly $34.96 million.

Is The Ethereum Foundation Running Out Of Money

The context behind these sales is a period of "mild austerity" for the Ethereum Foundation.

Currently holding around 172,000 ETH, the Foundation is tightening its belt to ensure it can support core protocol development for years to come.

This ambitious goal spans several sectors, including finance, communication, governance, operating systems, and even biotech applications.

Despite the sales, the Foundation continues to issue smaller grants, ensuring that affiliated projects do not lose momentum during this transition.

data.title: What's wrong with Ethereum?
data.description:
Author: Pavel Paramonov & Translation: Plain Language Blockchain

This article is primarily inspired by Vitalik's recent tweets about the current state and changes in the market. While the entire market is declining, it's difficult to pinpoint a specific individual, and I don't intend to do so.

I have worked with many Ethereum teams and invested in multiple protocols built on Ethereum on behalf of venture funds. In general, I used to be a huge fan of Ethereum and EVM-related things.

Unfortunately, I can no longer say the same thing, because I feel that Ethereum doesn't know where it's headed (and many others share this sentiment).

I don't want to discuss ETH's price movements, but I can't ignore the fact that the world's second-largest cryptocurrency has been extremely volatile. Regardless of global market trends, ETH behaves more like a stablecoin that's going off-target. This essay aims to explore what has happened to Ethereum over the past few years and why many are losing hope or have already lost hope. Ethereum didn't lose to Solana or other competitors; it lost to itself. When Ethereum introduced its Rollup-centric roadmap, almost everyone was excited. The promise at the time was that Rollups (and Validiums) would handle scaling, end-user transactions would occur on Rollups, and Ethereum would act as a validation layer—focusing on being the L1 for Rollups, rather than a direct-to-user L1. Developing Rollups is much faster and easier than developing L1, so the vision of "thousands upon thousands of Rollups" seems very likely and optimistic. Where did things go wrong? It turns out, everything went wrong. Endless arguments, ideology overriding needs, ongoing infighting within the community, an identity crisis, and abandoning the vision of "centralized aggregation" too late. Everything that could go wrong went wrong. Most of the community initially considered Max Resnick a completely incompetent villain, only to find he was right about almost everything. During his time at Consensys, Max offered numerous suggestions on how Ethereum should move forward, but these were met with criticism and little support. The most foolish peak was when the entire industry started debating whether a certain L2 layer was truly "Ethereum," for example: Viewpoint A: "Base is an extension of Ethereum; we've made huge contributions to the Ethereum ecosystem." Viewpoint B: "Base is not an extension of Ethereum; it's an independent entity." What the hell are we even discussing? How can this kind of dialogue guide Ethereum and its ecosystem towards a better future? Why are people seriously debating what constitutes core Ethereum and what it isn't? Don't we have more important issues to address? This ideological debate isn't a debate at all; it's a confrontation between two small circles trying to prove who's right. We don't need internal friction (PvP); we need external expansion (PvE). We need to understand that this isn't a confrontation between us, but rather a shared understanding of our problems and future. Unfortunately, many people prefer the pursuit of fleeting pleasure to considering that their opinions might be wrong. Technological ideology takes precedence over user needs. Based Rollups, Booster Rollups, Native Rollups, Gigagas Rollups, Keystore Rollups... Which is better, what will the future hold, and how do they connect? "This type is the future," "No, that type is the future." All these discussions... result in Arbitrum and Base continuing to dominate. Technological superiority brings advantages, but these advantages disappear when you compare "apples and pears" or "oranges and tangerines." They are too similar, so similar that users simply don't care. Nobody outside the bubble cares. One more pre-compilation, one less—you won't win. "Oh, we are actually 'Ethereum-aligned,' we have an advantage, we are very close to Ethereum, we embody its core values, and users will choose us." I want to ask, which values? And which users will choose you? @0xFacet became the first Rollup to reach Stage 2, they are a model of Ethereum alignment. But where are they? Where are their users, developers, tech KOLs, and those who support the Ethereum ecosystem and alignment? How many of you have heard of Facet? How many applications are available on Facet? I have no problem with Facet personally, I respect its founders. But where are those who keep saying we need more Stage 2 Rollups? I don't know, and you don't know either. Financial incentives are far more powerful than technical incentives. I used to be a fan of Taiko, especially their research on Based Rollups. This model has many advantages: stronger censorship resistance, neutrality, no risk of sequencer downtime, and L1 validators earning more money. Where's the trap? The trap lies in the finances behind the model. You can't force people to give up income for so-called "alignment." Arbitrum promised centralized sequencers, as did Scroll, Linea, zkSync, and Optimism. Where are they? Where are those sequencers? Every Rollup team writes in their documentation: "We currently use centralized sequencers, but have a strong desire for decentralization in the future." Almost no one delivers. Metis delivered, but luckily or unfortunately, people didn't care about Metis. Did I think they over-promised to pander to influential ETH purists (Maxis)? Yes. Did I think they really wanted a decentralized sequencer? Certainly, but it doesn't make business sense. Coinbase (Base) has a legal obligation to make as much money as possible and create value for the company. The same goes for other teams; why would you kill your own revenue stream? It simply doesn't make sense. Only about 5% of Base's revenue flows back to Ethereum. Rollups have never been an extension of Ethereum. Taiko had days when it paid Ethereum more in ordering fees than it collected from user transactions. Clearly, companies like Taiko have many other expenses besides paying Ethereum. Based Rollups or any vision of “Ethereum alignment” are only possible if the team is willing to forgo revenue. I haven't underestimated the importance of decentralization, security, and permissionlessness. But when your sole objective is “ideological correctness” rather than “user-centricity,” it all loses its meaning. Unsurprisingly, this weakness and the promise of “Ethereum alignment” have attracted a large number of grifters. Summarizing the consequences of centralized roadmaps: Eclipse, Movement, Blast, Gasp (Mangata), Mantra: These protocols were never intended for the long-term future. It's easy to hide behind masks of “Ethereum alignment,” making Ethereum better, and introducing SVM to Ethereum. They've all been, to some extent, “rugged.” All Rollups realize their tokens are practically useless because they pay fees with ETH while their tokens have almost no utility. Speculators realize you can create massive hype around a Rollup's central narrative and then cash out by dumping worthless tokens on retail investors. Ethereum has never acknowledged Polygon as a true L2, despite their significant role in securing ETH's value. If you believe Rollups are an extension of Ethereum's "culture," why not acknowledge a project so closely tied to Ethereum's security and usability? Polygon was crucial to Ethereum during the 2021 bull market, contributing significantly to ETH's growth as an asset. But yes, it's not L2 and doesn't deserve the Ethereum community's praise. If Polygon were L1, its valuation would be much higher. Even Paradigm, a top VC that has arguably contributed the most to the Ethereum ecosystem and even developed its own L2 (Ithaca), has shifted its focus to collaborating with Stripe on L1 (Tempo). I believe that when your biggest believer starts building your competitors, something is definitely wrong. The Ethereum Foundation (EF) lacks direction. While Ethereum is technically decentralized, its culture is highly centralized around Vitalik. Ethereum's internal circles are real. As people say, to succeed, all you need to do is get the attention of people around Vitalik and a few influential VCs. I'm not saying you have to agree with everything Vitalik says, but his views essentially define what's good and bad for Ethereum, and you can't compete with that. First, there's ultrasound money. Due to EIP-1559 and the merger, ETH's economic model became deflationary, suggesting it would be a better store of value than Bitcoin. But in 2024, ETH's annual inflation rate turned positive. So the vision of ultrasound money only lasted 3 years? That's not enough to become a store of value. This narrative is dead, and it was never true, because ETH wasn't designed to be a store of value; that's Bitcoin's mission, and you can't compete with that. Then, Ethereum couldn't decide whether its token was a commodity (inapplicable due to dynamic supply changes and staking mechanisms) or more like a tech stock (inapplicable because revenue wasn't sufficient to support a tech company's valuation). There's also the argument that ETH isn't money at all. What's going on? We need to choose a direction. Ethereum can't be multiple things at once—you either have a globally unified definition or you'll fall behind. Financial incentives…missing again. I still can't imagine a lead engineer like Péter Szilágyi receiving only about $100,000 a year for his contributions to Ethereum. This contributor, who has been here from the very beginning and helped Ethereum reach a market capitalization of $450 billion from scratch, received a salary of only 0.0001% of the market capitalization. The most influential and successful protocol in crypto history (second only to Bitcoin) didn't offer any incentives or equity. It's easy to justify hiding behind the creed of decentralization, open source, and permissionless principles: "We're not in it for the money, we're in it for progress." But you have to incentivize even the most loyal warriors, or they'll leave or take on private projects. Péter left, Danny Ryan left, and Dankrad Feist went straight to Tempo. Justin Drake and Dankrad accepted advisory positions at EigenLayer in 2024 and received token allocations, resulting in community resentment. These people at EF, earning a "peanut" salary (compared to FAANG companies and AI labs), are being attacked simply for making money and helping a protocol that wants to make Ethereum better (even if it's not Ethereum itself). Are you idiots? Sometimes I feel that if you're an honest, hardworking person on Ethereum, you're deprived of the right to earn money and expected to work like a slave to gain "approval" from Ethereum. EF has been dumping ETH to fund various operations and research. But perhaps they should pay their researchers enough first? Zero tolerance for adaptability. "Day 1. Ethereum will win. The decentralized blockchain with the highest uptime." We hear this every day, just like we hear Ethereum's excuses every day. Yes, Ethereum is expensive and slow. But we have Rollups, use Rollups, Rollups are Ethereum! Yes, ETH prices lag. But Ethereum has the largest developer ecosystem, we have a solid foundation, and demand will follow. Ethereum is the most decentralized! Solana is garbage, they lack client diversity. Ethereum is 100% uptime! Solana is garbage, it has crashed several times. Ethereum's network activity is lower than Solana's. That's because Solana's activity is mostly spam and smurfs. We are an ethical chain! You know, it makes me happy to see people realize their mistakes; it takes courage. But I think it might be too late. Ethereum has once again found the path it has needed to take in the long run, but progress remains slow. EF has indeed seen some changes recently: new leadership, treasury transparency, R&D restructuring, and so on. EF has started hiring young and talented DevRels and marketing talent like Abbas Khan, Binji, and Lou3e. But change must be fast. Ethereum must sprint to prove everyone wrong. Let's see if, after these reforms and changes at EF, we can see Ethereum become an exciting object again, rather than an object of blind, delusional faith and disappointment.
